query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Già era dritta in sù la fiamma e queta 2 per non dir più, e già da noi sen gia 3 con la licenza del dolce poeta,
4 quand’ un’altra, che dietro a lei venìa, 5 ne fece volger li occhi a la sua cima 6 per un confuso suon che fuor n’uscia.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Already she was erect upon the flame and quiet, 2 to say no more, and already she was departing from us 3 with the permission of the gentle poet,
4 when another, who was coming behind her, 5 made us turn our eyes to her summit 6 because of a confused sound that was coming out of it.
**Old English:**
1 Þa wæs heo rihte ofer ðære lige and gestilde, 2 ðæt ic ne mæg mare secgan, and ða fram us gewat 3 mid ðæs swetan leoðwyrhta leafe,
4 ða ða an oðer, ðe hire æfter com, 5 dyde us wendan ure gesihðe to hire heafde 6 for ðære gedrefednesse ðe ðær of com.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Come ’l bue cicilian che mugghiò prima 8 col pianto di colui, e ciò fu dritto, 9 che l’avea temperato con sua lima,
10 mugghiava con la voce de l’afflitto, 11 sì che, con tutto che fosse di rame, 12 pur el pareva dal dolor trafitto;
13 così, per non aver via né forame 14 dal principio nel foco, in suo linguaggio 15 si convertïan le parole grame.
query.result:
**English:**
7 Like the Sicilian bull that first lowed 8 with the plaint of him, and that was right, 9 since he had tempered it with his file,
10 it lowed with the voice of the afflicted, 11 so that, even though it was made of brass, 12 yet it seemed pierced by pain;
13 thus, for having no way or opening 14 from the beginning in the fire, in its language 15 the sorrowful words were transformed.
**Old English:**
7 Swa ðæt Sisilisce treow ðe ær gemægðe 8 mid ðæs wælgæstes wopum, and ðæt wæs riht, 9 forðæm he hine ær mid his feolan gefegode,
10 geomrode mid ðæs yrmðes reorde, 11 ðæt ðe, ðeah ðe he wære æren, 12 ðeah he ðurh ðone dolg wæs gedrefed;
13 swa ðurh ðæt fyr ða wædleasan word 14 æt fruman forð ne meahton on ða lyft 15 acurnon, ac ðær inne wunedon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Ma poscia ch’ebber colto lor vïaggio 17 su per la punta, dandole quel guizzo 18 che dato avea la lingua in lor passaggio,
19 udimmo dire: «O tu a cu’ io drizzo 20 la voce e che parlavi mo lombardo, 21 dicendo “Istra ten va, più non t’adizzo”,
22 perch’ io sia giunto forse alquanto tardo, 23 non t’incresca restare a parlar meco; 24 vedi che non incresce a me, e ardo!
25 Se tu pur mo in questo mondo cieco 26 caduto se’ di quella dolce terra 27 latina ond’ io mia colpa tutta reco,
28 dimmi se Romagnuoli han pace o guerra; 29 ch’io fui d’i monti là intra Orbino 30 e ’l giogo di che Tever si diserra».
query.result:
**English:**
16 But after they had taken their journey 17 up to the summit, giving it the jolt 18 that the tongue had given them in passing,
19 we heard a voice say: "O you to whom I address 20 my voice, and who just now spoke Lombard, 21 saying, 'Istra, go now, I won't bother you anymore',
22 even though I may have arrived somewhat late, 23 don't be annoyed to stay and talk to me; 24 see that it doesn't annoy me, and I'm burning!
25 If you have just now fallen into this blind world 26 from that sweet Latin land from which I bear all my guilt,
27 tell me if the Romagnols have peace or war; 28 for I was from the mountains there between Urbino 29 and the ridge from which the Tiber bursts forth."
**Old English:**
16 Ac siððan ðe hie hæfdon heora fær hæfde 17 upp ofer ðone munt, syllende him ðone hleop 18 ðe ðæt tunge hæfde sylleð on heora forðsiðe,
19 ða gehyrde we stefne secgan: "Eala ðu ðe ic to 20 minne stefne wende and ðu ær on Lumbardie spræce, 21 cweðende 'Istra, ga nu, ic ðe ne tæle leng',
22 ðeah ðe ic sie cumen sum ðing læt, 23 ne beo ðe læð ðæt ðu wunige and sprece wið mec; 24 geseoh ðæt hit ne beoð me læð, and ic byrne!
25 Gif ðu nu on ðisse blindan worulde 26 eart befeallen of ðære swetan Latinean eorðan 27 ðanon ic ealle mine gyltas bere,
28 sege me gif ða Romanie habbað sibbe oððe gewinn; 29 forðæm ic wæs of ðam muntum ðær betwux Urbinum 30 and ðam hrycge ðanon Tibre awealleð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Io era in giuso ancora attento e chino, 32 quando il mio duca mi tentò di costa, 33 dicendo: «Parla tu; questi è latino».
query.result:
**English:**
31 I was still attentive and bowed down below, 32 when my guide touched me on the side, 33 saying: "Speak, you; this man is Latin."
**Old English:**
31 Ic wæs ða giet ðær ufan and niðer, 32 ða me min latteow on ða sidan hrinde, 33 and cwæð: "Sprec ðu nu; ðes is Læden man."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 E io, ch’avea già pronta la risposta, 35 sanza indugio a parlare incominciai: 36 «O anima che se’ là giù nascosta,
37 Romagna tua non è, e non fu mai, 38 sanza guerra ne’ cuor de’ suoi tiranni; 39 ma ’n palese nessuna or vi lasciai.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And I, who had my answer ready, 35 began to speak without delay: 36 "O soul, who are hidden down there,
37 Romagna is not yours, and never was, 38 without war in the hearts of its tyrants; 39 but I left none of it openly at peace.
**Old English:**
34 And ic, ðe hæfde ða andsware gearu, 35 ða ongean ðam wordum ongan ic sprecan: 36 "Eala ðu sawl, ðe ðær eart niðer belocen,
37 ðin Romanie nis, and næfre wæs, 38 butan gewinne on ðara tyrana heortum; 39 ac on ðære sweotolan ic ðær nænne ne læfde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Ravenna sta come stata è molt’ anni: 41 l’aguglia da Polenta la si cova, 42 sì che Cervia ricuopre co’ suoi vanni.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Ravenna stands as it has stood for many years: 41 the eagle of Polenta broods over it, 42 so that Cervia is covered by its wings.
**Old English:**
40 Rafenna stent swa heo stód manig gear: 41 se earn of Polenta heo ðær oferhogað, 42 swa ðæt Cerfic is bewrigen mid his wengum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 La terra che fé già la lunga prova 44 e di Franceschi sanguinoso mucchio, 45 sotto le branche verdi si ritrova.
query.result:
**English:**
43 The land that once made the long trial 44 and bloody heap of Frenchmen, 45 is found again under the green boughs.
**Old English:**
43 Þæt land ðe ær geworhte ða longan geswinc 44 and ðara Francena blodigan heap, 45 under lyftlime limpeð eft.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 E ’l mastin vecchio e ’l nuovo da Verrucchio, 47 che fecer di Montagna il mal governo, 48 là dove soglion fan d’i denti succhio.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And the old and new mastiffs of Verrucchio, 47 who made Montagna's government evil, 48 are there, where they are accustomed to suck blood with their teeth.
**Old English:**
46 And ða ealdan and ða niwan mæstifeas of Verrucchio, 47 ðe worhton of Montagna ðone yflan gerefan, 48 ðær ðær hi wæron gewunode ðæt hi sudon mid ðæra toða.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Le città di Lamone e di Santerno 50 conduce il lïoncel dal nido bianco, 51 che muta parte da la state al verno.
query.result:
**English:**
49 The cities of Lamone and Santerno 50 the young lion leads from the white lair, 51 who changes his lair from summer to winter.
**Old English:**
49 Þa burgas Lamone and Santerno 50 lædeð se lið-leo of þam hwitan neste, 51 se ðe wended his wicum of sumere to wintra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 E quella cu’ il Savio bagna il fianco, 53 così com’ ella sie’ tra ’l piano e ’l monte, 54 tra tirannia si vive e stato franco.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And that which the Savio bathes its flank, 53 so that it lies between the plain and the mountain, 54 lives between tyranny and a free state.
**Old English:**
52 And ðæt ðe se Savio baðað ðone sidan, 53 swa swa heo sý betwux ðam felda and ðam munte, 54 betwux ðære teonunge and ðam frigan rīce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Ora chi se’, ti priego che ne conte; 56 non esser duro più ch’altri sia stato, 57 se ’l nome tuo nel mondo tegna fronte».
query.result:
**English:**
55 Now who are you, I beg you to tell us; 56 do not be harder than others have been, 57 if your name holds its head up in the world.”
**Old English:**
55 Nu ðu ðe secge, ic ðe bidde, hwa ðu sy; 56 ne beo ðu na ðonne oðre men syndon, 57 gif ðin noma on worulde wunað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Poscia che ’l foco alquanto ebbe rugghiato 59 al modo suo, l’aguta punta mosse 60 di qua, di là, e poi diè cotal fiato:
61 «S’i’ credesse che mia risposta fosse 62 a persona che mai tornasse al mondo, 63 questa fiamma staria sanza più scosse;
64 ma però che già mai di questo fondo 65 non tornò vivo alcun, s’i’ odo il vero, 66 sanza tema d’infamia ti rispondo.
query.result:
**English:**
58 After the fire had roared for a while 59 in its own way, it moved its sharp point 60 here and there, and then it spoke these words:
61 "If I believed that my answer would be 62 to someone who would ever return to the world, 63 this flame would remain still and not flicker;
64 but since no one has ever returned alive from this depth, 65 if what I hear is true, 66 I will answer you without fear of infamy.
**Old English:**
58 Þa ðæt fyr ða hwile hweop ða 59 on his wisan, ða wendan he ða scearpan ecg 60 on ða healfe, on ða healfe, and ða ðus wordum cwæð:
61 "Gif ic gelefde ðæt min andsware 62 wære ænigum men ðe eft to mannum cyme, 63 ðeos ligestode ða gyt unscyldig;
64 ac forðæm ðe næfre ðisne grund 65 ænig cwic æfter ðam ðe ic her wiste, 66 ic ðe secge butan ælcere sæcce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Io fui uom d’arme, e poi fui cordigliero, 68 credendomi, sì cinto, fare ammenda; 69 e certo il creder mio venìa intero,
70 se non fosse il gran prete, a cui mal prenda!, 71 che mi rimise ne le prime colpe; 72 e come e quare, voglio che m’intenda.
query.result:
**English:**
67 I was a man of arms, and then I was a Franciscan friar, 68 believing that, thus belted, I would make amends; 69 and certainly my belief would have been fulfilled,
70 had it not been for the great priest, may evil befall him!, 71 who threw me back into my former sins; 72 and how and why, I want you to understand.
**Old English:**
67 Ic wæs wer of wæpnum, and ða wæs ic munuc, 68 wenende me, swa begyrd, ðæt ic mihte gebetan; 69 and to soðan min geleafa wære gehealden,
70 nære se mæra preost, ðam sie yfel becume!, 71 se ðe me awearp eft on ða forman synne; 72 and hu and for hwi, ic wille ðæt ðu me gehyre.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Mentre ch’io forma fui d’ossa e di polpe 74 che la madre mi diè, l’opere mie 75 non furon leonine, ma di volpe.
query.result:
**English:**
73 While I was a form of bones and flesh 74 that my mother gave me, my actions 75 were not like a lion's, but like a fox's.
**Old English:**
73 Þa hwile þe ic wæs lichomanna 74 þe me min modor on woruld brohte, 75 ne wæron mine weorc lyonesse, ac foxes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Li accorgimenti e le coperte vie 77 io seppi tutte, e sì menai lor arte, 78 ch’al fine de la terra il suono uscie.
query.result:
**English:**
76 The stratagems and covert ways 77 I knew them all, and so I plied their art, 78 that to the ends of the earth the sound went forth.
**Old English:**
76 Þa rædas and þa diglan wegas 77 ic ealle cuþe and swa hyra cræftas lædde, 78 þæt to ðæs landes ende seo hleoðe com.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Quando mi vidi giunto in quella parte 80 di mia etade ove ciascun dovrebbe 81 calar le vele e raccoglier le sarte,
82 ciò che pria mi piacëa, allor m’increbbe, 83 e pentuto e confesso mi rendei; 84 ahi miser lasso! e giovato sarebbe.
query.result:
**English:**
79 When I saw myself arrived at that part 80 of my age where everyone should 81 lower the sails and gather in the ropes,
82 what I had previously enjoyed, then displeased me, 83 and I repented and confessed; 84 ah, wretched me! and it would have been beneficial.
**Old English:**
79 Þa ic me geseah cumen to ðære tide 80 mines lifes ðe gehwylc sceolde 81 his segl strycan and his scip rædan,
82 ða ongan me mislicen þæt me ær licode, 83 and ic me on mode geornlice 84 sarige and sorhful syngende bemænde; 85 eala, wla wla wla! wa bið ðam þe sceal 86 his sawle rædan and hine sylfne a 87 on ðam wyrrestan wicum wunian.
(Note: Lines 85-87 are not in the original Italian text, but were added by the Old English translator.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Lo principe d’i novi Farisei, 86 avendo guerra presso a Laterano, 87 e non con Saracin né con Giudei,
88 ché ciascun suo nimico era cristiano, 89 e nessun era stato a vincer Acri 90 né mercatante in terra di Soldano,
91 né sommo officio né ordini sacri 92 guardò in sé, né in me quel capestro 93 che solea fare i suoi cinti più macri.
query.result:
**English:**
85 The prince of the new Pharisees, 86 having war near the Lateran, 87 and not with Saracens or Jews,
88 for every enemy of his was a Christian, 89 and none had been to conquer Acre 90 or a merchant in the land of the Sultan,
91 nor did he consider in himself any high office or holy orders, 92 nor in me that cord 93 that used to make his belts thinner.
**Old English:**
85 Se cyning ðæra niwan Farisea, 86 hæbbende gewinn gehende ðæm Laterane, 87 and na mid Saraceniscum ne mid Iudeiscum,
88 forðæm ælc his feond wæs Cristen, 89 and nan ne wæs ðe wære æt ðæs Acres gewinne 90 ne ceápmann on ðæs Soldanes lande,
91 ne he ne beheold on him sylfum nan heah gesetness ne hálige hádas, 92 ne on me ðone ráp ðe wæs gewunod ðæt he his gyrdlas mácóde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Ma come Costantin chiese Silvestro 95 d’entro Siratti a guerir de la lebbre, 96 così mi chiese questi per maestro
97 a guerir de la sua superba febbre; 98 domandommi consiglio, e io tacetti 99 perché le sue parole parver ebbre.
query.result:
**English:**
94 But just as Constantine asked Sylvester 95 to heal him of leprosy from within Siratti, 96 so this man asked me to be his teacher,
97 to heal him of his proud fever; 98 he asked me for advice, and I was silent, 99 because his words seemed drunken.
**Old English:**
94 Ac swa swa Constantinus bæd Siluestrum 95 of Sirattiscum ðæt he hine gehælde 96 of þære licþrowunge, swa þes bad me
97 ðæt ic hine gehælde of his ofermode; 98 he bæd me redes, and ic ða swugode, 99 forðæm me þuhton his word ungesælige.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 E’ poi ridisse: “Tuo cuor non sospetti; 101 finor t’assolvo, e tu m’insegna fare 102 sì come Penestrino in terra getti.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And then he said again: “Let not your heart be troubled; 101 I absolve you completely, and you teach me how 102 to throw Penestrino to the ground.
**Old English:**
100 And ða eft he cwæð: “Ðin heorte ne beo na bregdon; 101 ic ðe fullice asolfe, and ðu me tæce 102 hu ic Penestrinum to eorðan gewurpe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Lo ciel poss’ io serrare e diserrare, 104 come tu sai; però son due le chiavi 105 che ’l mio antecessor non ebbe care”.
query.result:
**English:**
103 The heavens can I lock and unlock, 104 as you know; therefore there are two keys 105 that my predecessor did not cherish.
**Old English:**
103 Þone heofon mæg ic scyttan and unscyttan, 104 swa ðu wast; forðæm sind twegen ða cægðas 105 ðe min forma fæder næfre ne lufode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Allor mi pinser li argomenti gravi 107 là ’ve ’l tacer mi fu avviso ’l peggio, 108 e dissi: “Padre, da che tu mi lavi
109 di quel peccato ov’ io mo cader deggio, 110 lunga promessa con l’attender corto 111 ti farà trïunfar ne l’alto seggio”.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Then I pondered the weighty arguments 107 where silence seemed to me the worst course, 108 and I said: “Father, since you cleanse me 109 of that sin into which I must fall again, 110 a long promise with a short fulfillment 111 will make you triumph in the high seat.”
**Old English:**
106 Þa ic ða hefigan ðohtas þohte 107 þær me þæt þuhte þæt þegenlicost, 108 and ic cwæð: “Fæder, nu ðu me þone synn 109 afæstest, ðe ic sceal eft gewyrcan, 110 lange gehat mid læssan geornfulnesse 111 þe gedon mæg on þam hean setle.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Francesco venne poi, com’ io fu’ morto, 113 per me; ma un d’i neri cherubini 114 li disse: “Non portar: non mi far torto.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Francis came then, as I was dead, 113 for me; but one of the black cherubim 114 said to him: “Do not carry him off: do not wrong me.
**Old English:**
112 Franciscus com ða, ða ic wæs dead, 113 æfter me; ac an ðara sweartra cherubina 114 cwæð to him: “Ne ber ðu hine: ne do me teonan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Oh me dolente! come mi riscossi 122 quando mi prese dicendomi: “Forse 123 tu non pensavi ch’io löico fossi!”.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Oh, how I trembled when he seized me, 122 saying to me: “Perhaps you did not think that I was a logician!”
**Old English:**
121 Eala, wá lá wá! hú ic ðá forhted wæs, 122 ðá hé mé grípende cwæð: “Þú ne wéndest ná 123 ðæt ic lógiíce cúde!”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 A Minòs mi portò; e quelli attorse 125 otto volte la coda al dosso duro; 126 e poi che per gran rabbia la si morse,
127 disse: “Questi è d’i rei del foco furo”; 128 per ch’io là dove vedi son perduto, 129 e sì vestito, andando, mi rancuro».
query.result:
**English:**
124 He led me to Minos; and he, twisting 125 eight times his tail around his hardened back, 126 and then, for great rage, biting it,
127 said: “This one is for the fire’s kings”; 128 wherefore I, where you see me, am lost, 129 and thus, as you see, clothed, I go complaining.”
**Old English:**
124 He mec lædde to Minos; and he ða 125 eahtan siðan his tægl to ðam heardan hrycge; 126 and ða ðurh micelne grame hine sylfne bat,
127 cwæð: “Þes is ðara fyres cyninga”; 128 for ði ic ðær ðær ðu gesyhst forloren eom, 129 and ðus gewæded, gangende ic me geomrige”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Quand’ elli ebbe ’l suo dir così compiuto, 131 la fiamma dolorando si partio, 132 torcendo e dibattendo ’l corno aguto.
query.result:
**English:**
130 When he had thus completed his speech, 131 the flame departed, grieving, 132 twisting and lashing its sharp horn.
**Old English:**
130 Þa he hæfde his word ðus gecweden, 131 ða flamman geomrende of ðam fyre gewat, 132 wrigendum and wyrpendum ðone scearpne horn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Noi passamm’ oltre, e io e ’l duca mio, 134 su per lo scoglio infino in su l’altr’ arco 135 che cuopre ’l fosso in che si paga il fio
136 a quei che scommettendo acquistan carco.
query.result:
**English:**
133 We passed on, my leader and I, 134 up over the cliff to the next arch 135 that covers the pit where those pay their penalty
136 who, by gambling, acquire a burden.
**Old English:**
133 We forðferdon, ic and min latteow, 134 uppon ðone stan oð ðone oðerne boga 135 ðe ðone pytt oferwrið ðær ða forwyrnde 136 ðurh ða wyrpe ða wægan byrðe.
